Award.AwardTitle: Vacancy Engineering for Enhanced Strength and Toughness of Metals
Award.AbstractNarration:
1. Nontechnical Abstract

Strength (ability to bear mechanical load) and toughness (ability to resist fracture) are desired in civil and transportation infrastructure, manufacturing and processing, and bio-medical implants to make them stronger, safer, and lighter and energy efficient. Unfortunately, strength and toughness in metals are mutually exclusive - a fundamental challenge that remains to be resolved because the mechanism that controls strength in metals is inversely coupled with toughness. This research project aims to introduce a new type of mechanism, where atomic scale vacancies interact with existing defects to induce decoupling of strength and toughness. Such vacancy-defect interaction is not well understood because in conventional metals, vacancies do not play dominant roles. In addition, these mechanisms are strongly influenced by the internal structure and existing defect distribution in the metal as well as temperature. The experiments will be performed inside high-resolution microscopes, so the role of different deformation mechanisms can be seen in real time as strength and toughness are controlled and measured. The scientific outcome of this research will be new knowledge in atomic scale vacancy - defect interactions, which will be demonstrated through technological innovation in metals that are both strong and tough. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in crosscutting disciplines of metallurgy, mechanics, nanofabrication and microscopy to solve this highly coupled research problem. Academic outreach activities will be performed to attract the next generation workforce towards materials science & engineering.

2. Technical Abstract

Strength of metals originates from their capability of suppressing dislocation motion or plastic deformation. Toughness, on the other hand, requires large amount of plastic work before fracture. Because of such conflict, they are mutually exclusive. The current paradigm is to optimize, or in other words, compromise between strength and toughness. Contrarily, this research aims to maximize strength and toughness through synergistic multi-scale defect interactions (0D: vacancy, 1D: dislocations and 2D: grain/twin boundaries). Here, dislocation confinement in nano-crystalline metals is exploited to achieve high strength. At the same time, point defects (vacancies) are generated at ambient conditions, which facilitate diffusion-based plasticity without unlocking the dislocations. The net result is the unique co-existence of suppressed dislocation activities and pronounced diffusional plasticity without any change in grain size. This research is based on the hypothesis that it is possible to have both dislocation-based strength and diffusion-based deformability in the same grain at the same time and at ambient temperature. A unique material processing technique with temperature-current-stress synergy is proposed to generate the required vacancy concentration. This leads to a transformative concept; a three-way interaction among three dimensions of defects to maximize both strength and toughness. The nanoscale grain boundaries will lead to very high strength by impeding dislocation motion. The lack of ductility arising from small grains is removed by vacancies through diffusional plasticity in the grain boundaries. Finally, scalability of the proposed concept in meso and macroscopic manufacturing processing will be studied for feasibility in real life applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Objective: The overarching objective of this project was to determine the fundamentals of the interactions between a vacancy (a 0D defect) with stacking fault, dislocations, grain boundaries (1, 2 and 3D defects). The uniqueness of this concept is due to the literature, which cites 0D defects as unstable elements and ineffective to influence materials properties. The foundation of this project is our counter argument that instability is the key requirement for any atomic/defect restructuring; therefore, 0D defects can potentially transform the energetics of microstructural processing of metallic materials. Accordingly, we performed extensive fundamental research on the role of 0D defects on microstructure of metallic materials. The key accomplishments are given below.

Key Accomplishments (detail descriptions are given in following sections):

We have developed a microchip platform to experiment with vacancy generation and vacancy induced plasticity. The technique involves nanofabrication of micro-heaters and micro-electrodes in a 5 mm x 5 mm chip. The chip fits the transmission electron microscope (TEM) for real-time measurement of properties and (simultaneously) microstructural visualization. In the final year of the project, we have complemented the experimental technique with computational (molecular dynamics) modeling.

Our experimental and computational findings suggest that vacancy migration can be exploited to make 1D and 2D defects unstable. In particular, 3D defect clusters (such as stacking fault tetrahedra or voids) can be reduced by interaction with vacancies under a mechanical stress field. The implication is order of magnitude increase in defect mobility in metallic materials.

We demonstrated the unique control of diffusional plasticity through excess vacancies, while retaining dislocation starvation in nanocrystalline metals. Our proposed vacancy-based grain boundary engineering brings in strengthening due to grain size effect and toughening due to vacancies; both at the same time. This unique occurrence leads to the breakdown of the classical mutual exclusiveness of strength and ductility.

We demonstrated current based control of existing vacancies (instead of creating new ones) for vacancy engineering of mechanical properties. The difficulty in introducing excess vacancies in metals has been a road-block in this discipline. This was accomplished through the electro-migration phenomenon.

  We have performed time dependent studies to discover that the enhancements in strength and ductility are accompanied with enhanced creep. The fundamental mechanism remains to be the vacancy induced diffusion. This suggests that vacancy engineered metallic materials are prone to creep deformation.

This project has enabled training and experience of graduate and undergraduate students. Two PhD and one MS students were partially supported during various phases of this project. The PhD students received training in electron microscopy and nanofabrication. The MS student received training in physical metallurgy and electron backscattered diffraction phenomenon.

This project has resulted in 13 peer reviewed journal publication, co-authored with graduate students. 1 manuscript is under review and 1 more manuscript is under internal review for submission. The PI and his graduate students have presented the findings in 12 conference papers. In each year of this project, the students presented the findings in major international conferences such as the Materials Research Society Fall/Spring Meetings and the International Mechanical Engineering Congress & Exposition of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

The project has developed collaborative relationships and co-authored publications with colleagues from between Brown University, Purdue University, University of Florida, Air Force Research Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratories.

Experimental techniques developed in this project found applications beyond the science of nanocrystalline metallic materials. Generation of vacancies in wide bandgap semiconductors was studied to identify the role in device degradation. This has catalyzed collaborative efforts between the University of Florida and Air Force Research Laboratory collaborators.

As originally proposed, we have integrated this research with classroom by assigning Senior Capstone Design course projects at the Pennsylvania State University. One undergraduate student was trained in specimen preparation for metallurgical studies.

As originally proposed, hands on activities themed as 'Touch the Mind' were performed in a local Elementary School. The students created 3 dimensional objects using a generic software (3D Objects coming with Microsoft Windows), which were printed using a desktop 3D printer.   

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2019
Modified by: Md A Haque
